div.head: Of the Abram, his de≈øcription.
div.p: THe Abram Coue, is a lu≈øtie ≈øtrong Roague, who walketh with a Slade about his Quarrous (a ≈øh√©ete about his body) Trining, hanging to his hammes, bandeliere-wi≈øe, for all the world as Cut-pur≈øes and Th√©eues weare their ≈øh√©etes to the Gallowes, in which their Tru ‚Ä¢ s are to bury them: oftentimes (becau≈øe h√©e ≈øcornes to follow any fa≈øhions of Ho≈øe,) h√©e goes without br√©eches, a cut Ierkin with hanging fl√©eues (in imitation of our Gallants,) but no Sa ‚Ä¢ tin or Chamblet elbowes, for both his legges and armes are bare, hauing no Commi≈ø≈øion to couer his body, that is to ≈øay, no ≈øhirt: A face ≈øtaring like a Sara≈øin, his hayre long and filthily knotted, for h√©e k√©epes no Barber: a good Filch (or Staffe) of growne A≈øh, or el≈øe Hazell, in his Famble (in his Hand) and ≈øometimes a ≈øharpe ≈øticke, on which h√©e hangeth Ruffe-pecke (Bacon.) div.head: Their Markes.
div.p: SOme of the≈øe Abrams haue the Letters E. and R. vpon their armes: ≈øome haue Cro≈ø≈øes, and ≈øome other marke, all of them carrying a blew colour: ≈øome weare an iron ring, &c. which markes are printed vpon their fle≈øh, by tying their arme hard with two ≈øtrings thr√©e or feure inches a≈øunder, and then with a ≈øharpe Awle pricking or raizing the ≈økinne, to ≈øuch a figure or print as they be≈øt fancy, they rub that place with burnt paper, pi≈ø≈øe and Gunpowder, which being hard rubd in, and ≈øuffered to dry, ≈øtickes in the fle≈øh a long time after, when the≈øe markes faile, they renew them at plea≈øure. If you examine them how the≈øe Letters or Figures are printed vpon their armes, they will tell you it is the Marke of Bedlam, but the truth is, they are made as I haue reported.

And to colour their villanie the better, euery one of the≈øe Abrams hath a ≈øeuerall ge≈øture in playing his part: ≈øome make an horrid noy≈øe, hollowly ≈øounding: ≈øome whoope, ≈øome hollow, ≈øome ≈øhew onely a kinde of wilde di≈øtracted vgly looke, vttering a ≈øimple kinde of Mawnding, with the≈øe addition of words (Well and Wi≈øely.) div.p: THe fir≈øt beginnes Good Vr≈øhip. Mai≈øter, or good Vr≈øhips Rulers of this place, be≈øtow your reward on a poore man that hath lyen in Bedlam without Bi≈øhops-gate three yeeres, foure moneths, and nine dayes, And be≈øtow one piece of your ≈ømall ≈øiluer towards his fees, which he is indebted there, the ≈øumme of three pounds, thirteene ≈øhillings, ≈øeauen pence, halfe-penny, (or to ≈øuch effect,) and hath not wherewith to pay the ≈øame, but by the good help of Vr≈øhipfull and well di≈øpo≈øed people, and God to reward them for it.

div.head: Of Counterfeit Souldiers.
div.p: THe≈øe may well be called Counterfeit Souldiers, for not one (≈øcarce) among the whole Armie of them, euer di≈øcharged ≈øo much as a Caliner: nothing makes them Souldiers but old Mandilions, which they buy at the Broakers. div.p: GEntle Rulers of this place, be≈øtow your reward vpon poore Souldiers, that are viterly maymed and ≈øpoyled in her Maie≈øties late warres, as vvell for Gods cau≈øe as her Maie≈øties and yours. div.p: THe Seales of Noblemen, Gentlemen, Iu≈øtices, or any other who haue authoritie to v≈øe Seales, are grauen in Siluer, Copper, or ≈øome hard ≈øtuffe: and tho≈øe things which are ≈øo grauen ≈øeale the Armes or ≈øuch like with ≈øharpe edges, and with a round circle enclo≈øing it, as if it were cut with an in≈øtrument of St√©ele, and it maketh a neate and d√©epe impre≈ø≈øion: but the≈øe counterfeit Ierkes (or Seales) are grauen with the point of a knife, vpon a ≈øtickes end, who≈øe roundne≈ø≈øe may well be perceiued from the circle of a common turnde Seale: the≈øe for the mo≈øt part bearing the ill fauoured ≈øhape of a Buhars Nab, or a Prancers Nab (a Dogges head, or a Hor≈øes,) and ≈øometimes an Vnicornes, and ≈øuch like: the Counterfeit Ierke hauing no Circle about the edges. div.p:

div.head: Of Clapperdogeons.
div.p:

div.head: Of their Mawnd.
div.p: THis Pallyard (or Artifieiall Clapperdogeon, who carryeth about him the great Cleyme) to ≈øtirre compa≈ø≈øion vp in peoples hearts, thus acteth his part: H√©e ≈ølides to the earth by his ≈øtaffe, and lying pittiou≈øly on the ground, makes a fearefull horrid ≈øtrange noy≈øe, through an hoar≈øe throate vttering the≈øe lamentable tunes: Ah the vr≈øhip of God looke out with your mereifull eyne, one pittifull looke vpon ≈øore, lame, grieued and impudent (for impotent) people, ≈øore troubled with the grieuous di≈øea≈øe, and haue no re≈øt day nor night by the Canker and Worme, that continually eateth the fle≈øh from the bone: for the Vr≈øhip of God be≈øtow one Cro≈ø≈øe of your ≈ømall ≈øiluer; to buy him ≈øalue and oyntment, to ca≈øe the poore wretched body; that neuer taketh re≈øt: and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to reward you for it in heauen. div.p: THey take Crow-foote, Sperewort, and Salt, and brui≈øing the≈øe together, they lay them vpon the place of the body which they de≈øire to make ≈øore: the ≈økinne by this meanes being fretted, they fir≈øt clappe a linnen cloath, till it ≈øticke fa≈øt, which plucked off, the raw fle≈øh hath Rats-bane throwne vpon it, to make it looke vgly: and then ca≈øt ouer that a cloath, which is alwayes bloudy and filthy, which they doe ≈øo often, that in the end in this hurt they f√©ele no paine, neyther de≈øire they to haue it healed, but with their Doxies will trauell (for all their great Cleymes) from Fayre to Fayre, and from Market to Market, being able by their Mawnding to get fiue Bordes (that is, fiue ≈øhillings) in a w√©eke, in money and Corne. div.head: Of their Names.
div.p: EVery one of them hath a peculiar Nicke-name, proper to him≈øelfe, by the which h√©e is more knowne, more inquired after by his brothers, and in common familiaritie more ≈øaluted, then by his owne true name: yea, the fal≈øe is v≈øed ≈øo much that the true is forgotten. div.head: Of their Libkins or Lodgings.
div.p:
